title: Prohibits the imposition of accident response service fees
summary: Prohibits the imposition of accident response service fees on insurance companies, drivers or owners of a motor vehicle, or any other person following an accident.

S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K
       ________________________________________________________________________

                                         2277

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                   I N  S E N A T E

                                   January 18, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced  by  Sen.  KRUGER -- read twice and ordered printed, and when
         printed to be committed to the Committee on Transportation

       AN ACT to amend the vehicle and traffic law, in relation to  prohibiting
         the imposition of accident response service fees

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Article 11 of the vehicle and traffic  law  is  amended  by
    2  adding a new section 389 to read as follows:
    3    S 389. ACCIDENT RESPONSE SERVICE FEE. 1. AS USED IN THIS SECTION:
    4    (A)  "ACCIDENT  RESPONSE  SERVICE  FEE"  MEANS  A  FEE IMPOSED FOR THE
    5  RESPONSE OR INVESTIGATION OF A MOTOR VEHICLE ACCIDENT BY A LAW  ENFORCE-
    6  MENT AGENCY; AND
    7    (B) "ENTITY" MEANS:
    8    (I) THE STATE;
    9    (II) A POLITICAL SUBDIVISION OF THE STATE, INCLUDING:
   10    A. A COUNTY;
   11    B. A CITY;
   12    C. A BOROUGH;
   13    D. AN INCORPORATED TOWN;
   14    E. A TOWNSHIP; OR
   15    F. A HOME-RULED MUNICIPALITY; AND
   16    (III)  ANY  GOVERNMENTAL  ENTITY  OR AGENCY OR DEPARTMENT OF A GOVERN-
   17  MENTAL ENTITY OR AGENCY.
   18    2. NOTWITHSTANDING ANY PROVISION OF LAW TO THE CONTRARY, A  PERSON  OR
   19  ENTITY  SHALL  NOT IMPOSE AN ACCIDENT RESPONSE SERVICE FEE ON OR FROM AN
   20  INSURANCE COMPANY, THE DRIVER OR OWNER OF A MOTOR VEHICLE, OR ANY  OTHER
   21  PERSON.
   22    S 2. This act shall take effect on the one hundred eightieth day after
   23  it shall have become a law.

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2277

TITLE OF BILL:

An act to amend the vehicle and traffic law, in relation to prohibiting
the imposition of accident response service fees

PURPOSE:

To prohibit municipalities from imposing additional fees and taxes on
motorists involved in an accident for emergency response services.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Adds a new section 389 to the Vehicle and Traffic Law

EXISTING LAW:

There is no law prohibiting this practice in New York State.

JUSTIFICATION:

The City of New York has proposed to implement a "crash tax," a fee
between $365.00 and $490.00 on July 1, 2011. Most drivers are taxpayers
who already pay for the emergency responders, both Fire and EMS who
respond to the scene of a car accident. The proposal amounts to a double
taxation on the residents of not just New York City, but the State as
well. Insurance companies have already expressed unwillingness to pay
the fee, thereby leaving motorists the choice of either paying for help
or refusing the help that they might need in a car accident. This opens
the door to a new series of litigation should the responders be turned
away by someone who later is discovered to have serious life threatening
injuries.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:

This is a new bill.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

None to the State at this time.

LOCAL FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

Allegedly this double tax would raise approximately $1,000,000.00 per
year.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

One hundred and eighty days after it becomes a law.
